persona.name: Gael Emiliano Zamora

occupation.title: Freelance Graphic Designer and Cultural Events Organizer; part-time barista
occupation.organization: Self-employed / freelance (clients: local cafes, independent labels, small NGOs, cultural promoters). Works part-time at a neighborhood café and occasionally contracts with a small creative studio for larger projects.
occupation.description:
Gael works primarily as a freelance graphic designer focused on branding, poster and gig flyer design, editorial layouts for small magazines and zines, and social-media visual packages. He is often hired by independent musicians, small restaurants, local art spaces, NGOs, and start-ups needing inexpensive design with cultural credibility. Income comes from a mix of client jobs (30-50%), part-time café wages (20-30%), small teaching gigs and workshops (5-10%), and occasional sales of limited-run prints and zines (5-10%).

Responsibilities and typical tasks:
- Meeting clients to discuss brief and budget, translating verbal ideas into sketches and mood boards.
- Producing proposals, logo concepts, posters, album or EP covers, social media assets, and print files.
- Managing production relationships: coordinating with printers for risograph/offset prints, selecting paper stocks and overseeing proofs.
- Running social media for his own projects and a couple of regular clients (scheduling posts, curating grids, basic analytics).
- Assisting in small-scale event organization: booking a DJ, designing and distributing flyers, liaising with neighborhood venues and municipal permits when necessary.
- Working barista shifts: preparing espresso drinks, front-of-house service, and light inventory tasks.

Skills and expertise in occupation:
- Strong typographic sense, hand-lettering, and layout composition.
- Proficiency in Adobe Creative Suite (Illustrator, Photoshop, InDesign), Figma for quick web/mockups, and Lightroom for photo editing.
- Basic HTML/CSS knowledge (can build or edit simple landing pages and e-mail templates).
- Good eye for print production, capable of preparing files for both digital and analog printing processes.
- Project and client management: quotes, contracts (simple), scheduling, revisions, and delivery.

Challenges and constraints:
- Income instability; frequently negotiates low budgets and accepts speculative work to build portfolio and relationships.
- Competition with low-cost designers and platform-driven marketplaces pushing prices down.
- Occasionally struggles with delayed client payments and cashflow peaks/troughs.
- Time management conflict between paid client work and time-consuming personal/collective cultural projects.

persona.education: Bachelor's degree in Visual Communication / Diseño Gráfico from Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México (UNAM). Completed a two-semester exchange/studio program at a private arts school in Puebla focused on typography and editorial design. Took evening courses in front-end web basics and photography. Did not pursue postgraduate studies due to financial constraints and commitments to freelance work.
long_term_goals: Build a stable creative practice (studio or small collective) that allows steady freelance income and the time to make personal art projects.
Be financially independent from his parents and maintain a modest apartment in Mexico City or another culturally vibrant Mexican city.
Co-produce at least two community cultural projects (neighborhood festival, mural program, or independent zine fair) per year.
Travel broadly across Latin America and spend extended periods in Oaxaca and Buenos Aires for cultural exchange and collaborations.
Achieve a balanced life with reliable savings (emergency fund of 3-6 months), access to healthcare, and time for friendships and art.
Contribute to progressive political causes (community healthcare, arts funding, anti-corruption) through activism and design work.
Learn conversational Portuguese and improve English to a professional level for international gigs.
Eventually teach occasional workshops for young people from his neighborhood about design and freelancing basics.
persona.style: Gael speaks with a Mexico City urban Spanish accent, mixing colloquial CDMX slang with cultured turns of phrase learned at university. He code-switches to English for technical or pop-culture references and occasionally uses anglicisms when talking about design or technology. Mannerisms include fast hand gestures when excited, a habit of tucking hair behind his ear while concentrating, and a small laugh that punctuates critical comments to soften them. He dresses in an unpretentious, urban-creative way: well-worn denim, thrifted shirts, a simple corduroy jacket, canvas sneakers, and an always-on canvas tote or backpack carrying a sketchbook, laptop, and camera. He favors honest, conversational tone in speech — candid, warm, occasionally sarcastic — and tends to add music or film references in conversations. On social media he curates an aesthetic feed but writes humble, conversational captions; in person he prefers direct eye contact and quick jokes. He is comfortable in crowded, lively spaces (cafés, concerts, markets) and leans into small talk to find collaborators, but he is also capable of quiet focus when working alone in a studio or café.

traits: Curious and experimental — loves trying new art techniques, music, and foods.
Sociable and warm — makes friends easily at shows, cafes, and workshops.
Practical and resourceful — figures out low-cost production methods and uses local networks to get things done.
Competitive about craft — takes pride in typographic choices and pixel-perfect layouts.
Generous and community-minded — willing to trade work for favors or to help cultural projects with limited budgets.
Impatient with bureaucracy and slow institutional processes.
Resilient but occasionally stressed by financial instability and deadlines.
Self-reflective and open to feedback — seeks mentorship and iterates on his work.
Skeptical of purely profit-driven enterprises, prefers meaningful collaborations.
Playful sense of humor, often ironic; sometimes uses sarcasm to deflect vulnerability.
Values authenticity and dislikes pretension or elitist attitudes.
Tends to procrastinate on administrative tasks but excels in creative problem-solving under pressure.

big_five.openness: Very high — voracious reader of design blogs, enjoys travel, new music, and artistic experimentation.
big_five.conscientiousness: Moderate — reliable for creative delivery but disorganized with paperwork and finances.
big_five.extraversion: High — energized by social events, frequent participant in local gigs and meetups.
big_five.agreeableness: Moderate-high — cooperative and helpful, but willing to push back on unfair requests or exploitative conditions.
big_five.neuroticism: Moderate — experiences anxiety around money and important deadlines, but uses exercise and social support to manage stress.

Live music (indie rock, cumbia rebajada, Mexican alternative, contemporary rumba).
Street food and mercados — especially tacos al pastor, tlacoyos, esquites, and mole in family recipes.
Contemporary art openings, small gallery shows, and mural work in the city.
Travel to other Mexican states for cultural exchange (Oaxaca for textiles and mezcal; Guadalajara for music; Puebla for ceramics).
Photography — candid street photography with a preference for film simulation presets.
Local festivals and neighborhood cultural programming (alley concerts, zine fairs).
Podcasts about politics, design history, and music scene interviews.
Documentary films and independent cinema (Mexican new wave, Latin American auteurs).
Learning new creative skills through online tutorials (motion graphics, risograph printing).
Collecting second-hand clothing and supporting local makers.
Small-batch coffee (single origin, alternative brew methods) and occasional filter coffee rituals.
Craft mezcal tastings and learning about regional varieties.
Vinyl collecting — especially Mexican pressings and Latin alternative albums.
Sustainable lifestyle choices within budget: reusable water bottle, second-hand furniture, urban bike commuting.
Using social media platforms primarily for promotion, cultural discovery, and networking.
Supporting independent bookstores and zine shops.
Attending workshops to both teach and learn (letterpress, poster design, sound basics).
Participating in collaborative art projects and community murals.
Following local politics and community assembly meetings that affect urban cultural life.
likes: Warm, busy cafés with good Wi-Fi and reliable espresso machines (favors independent cafés in Roma, Condesa and Coyoacán).
Mexican street tacos (pastor and suadero) from trusted stalls.
Risograph prints, tactile paper stock, and hand-made zines.
Deep, bass-heavy cumbia nights and intimate indie shows.
Late-afternoon light for photography and sketching outdoors.
A certain playlist structure: mellow morning lo-fi, productive afternoon indie-electronic, energetic late-night cumbia/rock.
Collaborative creative sessions (co-working afternoons with friends).
Minimal but thoughtful branding — clarity over gimmicks.
Buying tea leaves and locally-made jams as gifts rather than expensive imported goods.
Spending an afternoon wandering the Bazar del Sábado or local markets for inspiration.
Podcasts in Spanish and English about design, culture, and politics.
Simple rituals: espresso at 10 AM, sketchbook time, and calling his mother on Sundays.
Affordable vintage stores and tailoring to adapt second-hand items.
Spontaneous short trips to nearby towns on long weekends.
Spicy, citrus-forward foods (limón, chile de árbol, salsa verde).
Open-air concerts and outdoor screenings.
Collaborations with friends over paid but low-margin jobs for exposure and community building.
Small social gatherings at home with close friends — cooking together and sharing playlists.
Street art and murals with political or social commentary.
Transparent, friendly client relationships where expectations are clear from the start.
dislikes: Pretentious art-world language and festivals that exclude local communities.
Large corporate gigs that require creative compromises for mass-market platitudes.
Excessive bureaucracy for small cultural events and arbitrary permit costs.
People who ghost on payments or repeatedly delay invoices.
Overly curated social media that feels inauthentic and performative.
Long commutes across the city when time could be spent on creative work or rest.
Neoliberal rhetoric that blames individuals for structural inequality.
Unhelpful customer service in public services and government offices.
Gated communities and cultural spaces that exclude local residents.
Crowded touristic spots at peak times that have lost local flavor.
Fast-fashion brands that push unsustainable consumption.
Silos between traditional craftsmen and contemporary creative industries.
Policies that reduce funding for public arts and neighborhood cultural programs.
Any product or restaurant that passes off inauthentic souvenirs as 'Mexican experience' to tourists.
Being lectured rather than engaged in collaborative conversation.
media_and_tech_preferences: Primary phone: Android, heavy daily use for messaging, photo editing and social posting.
Favorite apps: Instagram (portfolio and discovery), WhatsApp (everyday communication), Spotify (music and playlists), Twitter/X (political and cultural news), Pinterest for mood boards.
Streaming services: subscribes to an affordable music streaming service (Spotify or Deezer) and uses a shared or free tier for video streaming (YouTube, occasional Netflix).
Design resources: follows Behance, Typewolf, and community type foundries; regularly buys fonts from independent Latin American designers.
Hardware: a used MacBook Pro or equivalent for design work, an older mirrorless camera for street photography, a mechanical keyboard he likes for long layout sessions.
Communication style: prefers voice notes in WhatsApp for nuanced conversation rather than long text threads; uses DMs for quick client check-ins.
Content creation: posts process images and behind-the-scenes on Instagram Stories; occasionally posts subtitled videos explaining a project.
Privacy stance: somewhat concerned about data harvesting by platforms but trades some privacy for the network and exposure those platforms provide.
Purchasing behavior: price-sensitive but willing to pay for unique craft or high-quality production when affordable; often supports crowdfunded creative projects.

beliefs: The government should guarantee access to universal public healthcare; healthcare is a right, not a commodity.
Public investment in education and cultural programs is essential for social mobility and healthier cities.
Corruption is endemic in many institutions and must be fought through transparency and civic oversight.
Economic policies should prioritize reducing inequality through progressive taxation and social programs.
Young people should be supported with vocational training, apprenticeships, and affordable housing options.
Arts and culture are essential public goods that deserve stable public funding, not only private patronage.
Local businesses and markets should be protected from displacement by large chains and gentrification pressures.
Indigenous and mestizo cultural expressions must be respected and given space in urban cultural life.
Female and LGBTQ+ rights should be robustly protected; public policies must reduce gender violence and discrimination.
Mental health care should be destigmatized and made affordable and accessible to all socioeconomic groups.
Climate change is a real threat and cities must invest in green infrastructure, waste reduction, and sustainable transit.
Public transport should be safe, affordable, frequent, and prioritized over car-centered infrastructure.
Policing needs reform; community-based alternatives and accountability mechanisms are necessary.
Community decision-making (juntas, assemblies) can lead to better local outcomes than top-down directives.
Gig economy work should include basic protections and portability of benefits; informal workers deserve greater security.
Small creative enterprises are engines of cultural life and local economies and should be incentivized.
Tourism policies should prioritize community benefit and avoid cultural commodification.
Universities must be accessible and oriented toward public service as well as research and culture.
Healthcare for reproductive rights must be protected and accessible.
Open, democratic debate on public radio and independent media is vital; journalists should be protected.
Digital platforms can amplify voices but also spread misinformation; digital literacy needs to be part of education.
Trust in government institutions is low because of repeating scandals; reforms and citizen oversight can rebuild confidence.
A strong safety net reduces crime by addressing root causes like poverty and marginalization.
Artists should be fairly paid for their work and have access to contracts and legal protections.
Creative collaborations between older artisans and contemporary designers can be mutually beneficial if done respectfully.
Startup culture sometimes romanticizes precarious labor; entrepreneurship should not be an excuse for lack of labor protections.
Community spaces (libraries, cultural centers) must be defended against privatization and budget cuts.
Foreign investment is acceptable if it respects local labor standards and cultural sovereignty.
Voting is important even if parties disappoint; participation also includes local activism and community organizing.
Public healthcare systems should integrate traditional medicine knowledge where appropriate and evidence-based.
Urban public spaces should be reclaimed from cars and developed for people, play, markets and performance.
Private philanthropy cannot replace public responsibility for welfare and cultural provision.
Youth employment programs need better coordination so creative workers can make livelihoods without exploitation.
Diasporic and migratory ties are part of Mexican modernity; migration policy must respect human rights.
Technology companies operating in Mexico should be regulated for tax fairness and data protection.
Language diversity (indigenous languages) deserves official protection and promotion, including cultural programming.
Community stress and anxiety are worsened by economic uncertainty; social policies should aim to reduce precarity.

Typography and layout: skilled in typographic hierarchies, kerning, and editorial composition for both print and digital.
Branding: able to craft small-scale visual identities and adapt them across print and social assets.
Print production knowledge: experience with risograph, screenprinting, offset printing, die-cuts, and proof checking.
Basic front-end web skills: HTML/CSS familiarity for landing pages and email templates; comfortable with Figma for prototypes.
Photography: competent street and documentary photography; uses Lightroom and manual camera controls.
Event organization: booking, promotion, coordinating volunteers, and handling basic budgets for small cultural events.
Social media content creation: strategy for Instagram, Story editing, short-form video basics for Reels/TikTok.
Client communication: articulates creative rationale, writes simple contracts, negotiates scope and timelines.
Spanish (native) and practical English — can work with international clients at a conversational/professional level.
Basic bookkeeping and invoice management using spreadsheet templates and online payment platforms.
Public speaking: comfortable facilitating workshops and running informal design talks.
DIY skills: basic carpentry for exhibition setups and simple sign fabrication.
Rapid prototyping: quick mockups for pitches and low-fidelity deliverables when budgets are small.
Community outreach and relationship-building with local vendors, musicians, and cultural organizations.

general: Often begins projects with hand sketches and mood-collage before moving to digital.
Uses voice notes extensively for quick client and friend communications.
Keeps a small analog sketchbook for ideas and a separate Moleskine for task lists (which sometimes goes un-updated).
Is active in local creative WhatsApp and Telegram groups to find gigs, collaborators, and event invitations.
Prefers to meet new clients in person at a café to assess chemistry before accepting low-budget work.
Regularly cycles or takes micro-movilidad (shared scooter) around the neighborhood for short trips.
Buys groceries and cooks simple meals most evenings to save money, but eats out on weekends.
Sometimes accepts free or low-paid work in exchange for exposure, but learns to put boundaries after negative experiences.
Tends to binge-design before deadlines and then needs a slow recovery period afterwards.
Volunteers time occasionally for community events important to his neighborhood.

morning: Wakes around 8:00 - 9:00 AM depending on barista shift schedule.
Starts the day with a double espresso or pour-over at home, checks messages and client emails.
Skims design inspiration feeds and saves references into a 'mood board' collection.
If not working a barista shift, goes to a café to do concentrated client work and invoices.
workday: Splits time between client deadlines and production: morning for deep design focus, afternoon meetings and proofs.
Schedules barista shifts two to three times per week (mornings or early evenings).
Meets with printers or attends community meetings as needed for event planning.
Takes a midday walk to clear his head and shoot street photos for personal projects.
evening: Attends gallery openings, gigs, or community assemblies two to three times per week; sometimes hosts friends at home for music and food.
Edits photos or works on personal zines late at night a few times per month.
Checks finances, updates invoices and chases late payments before bed if a project is in progress.
Winds down with a short playlist and reads a chapter of a book or listens to a podcast.
weekend: Runs errands and visits markets in the morning, meets friends for long lunches, and often participates in pop-up markets or fairs where he sells prints.
Occasionally takes day trips to nearby towns for inspiration and sourcing artisanal materials.
Leads or attends collaborative workshops (letterpress, zine-making) or participates in collective studio sessions.

health.physical_health: Generally good overall. Average build, occasional seasonal allergies, dentist-verified cavity treated last year. Exercises irregularly — cycles and walks frequently but does not have a formal exercise plan. Sleeps 6-7 hours most nights but can have disrupted sleep before major deadlines.
health.mental_health: Prone to anxiety during financial uncertainty and looming client deadlines. Has experienced mild depressive episodes around periods of low work but has supportive friendships and uses creative work as coping. Has tried therapy (CBT-style) for a few months with positive effects but cannot always afford continuous sessions. Practices small mental health rituals: journaling, short runs, and talking with close friends.
health.medical_history: No chronic medical conditions. Received all childhood vaccinations. Occasionally uses over-the-counter medication for colds and headaches. Has none of the major hereditary illnesses known in the immediate family, though a paternal grandparent had type 2 diabetes.
health.healthcare_access: Mostly uses public healthcare services for routine care due to limited private insurance. Supports expansion of public healthcare and is looking into low-cost private plans for dental or specialist care when savings allow.
health.substance_use: Drinks socially — beer, mezcal on special occasions, coffee daily (moderate intake). Does not smoke regularly; smokes occasionally in social settings. Avoids heavy drug use; has tried cannabis a few times in social and creative settings.

relationships.name: Mariana Zamora
relationships.description: Lives in the south of CDMX in a multi-family home. Works in a small administrative role in a municipal office. Practical, supportive, worries about Gael's financial stability and safety. Calls weekly and sends care packages of homemade food and small cash when emergencies arise.

relationships.name: Héctor Zamora
relationships.description: Runs a small independent hardware store. Lives in a neighboring municipality. Sparing with praise but proud of Gael's craft. Pushed Gael to learn practical skills and to pursue stable work when younger. Relationship is cordial but not close.

relationships.name: Luz Ortega
relationships.description: Studying to be a primary school teacher at a local university. Close relationship, exchanges design tips with Gael and asks him to design flyers for school events. They text daily; she is one of his strongest emotional supports.

relationships.name: Santi (Santiago)
relationships.description: Musician and occasional co-organizer. They co-design posters for local shows and run a small monthly series of neighborhood concerts. Gael trusts Santi with long-term collaborations.

relationships.name: Ana Pérez
relationships.description: Dating on and off for the last year. Works in a cultural NGO. They share political views and attend protests together; relationship is affectionate but not exclusive.

relationships.name: Alondra
relationships.description: Provides critique, career advice, and occasional referrals to paid gigs. Met Gael at UNAM and stays connected for portfolio reviews.

relationships.name: Neighborhood network
relationships.description: A loose web of café owners, musicians, screenprinters, printers, and small gallery organizers who regularly trade favors, build small cultural events, and refer clients.

other_facts: Born and raised in a middle-class, mestizo family in the outskirts of Mexico City; moved to Roma Norte for university and creative networks.
Given name 'Gael' chosen because parents liked the sound; middle name Emiliano after an uncle who was politically engaged in local activism.
Grew up bilingual in some household phrases: Spanish main, occasional family-level mix with indigenous terms from grandparents' heritage.
First memory of making art: drawing concert posters for a high-school band and taping them around the school courtyard.
At university, he joined a small zine collective that introduced him to risograph printing and collective publication practices.
Worked as a barista through college to pay tuition and build contacts in the café scene where many cultural exchanges happen.
Has been ticketed once for illegal street vending while helping run a pop-up market; learned about navigating municipal permits since then.
Owns a battered notebook full of sketches, ideas, and contact numbers — he treats it like a personal archive.
Was part of a short-lived band in college (played tambourine and hand percussion), still keeps occasional guest appearances.
Has had several client disputes over scope creep; now insists on written confirmations and a small upfront deposit.
Donates small amounts to causes he believes in: community health clinics, local artists' mutual aid funds, and migrant support NGOs.
Is an avid follower of local municipal council meetings when neighborhood cultural spaces are threatened.
Has a modest online portfolio site and a printed portfolio book used for in-person client meetings.
Sometimes takes long overnight bus trips to other states to attend a festival or meet a craftsman for a collaborative project.
Owns a beloved second-hand film camera inherited from a neighbor; uses it for personal photo projects and occasional print sales.
Once collaborated with a collective to paint a mural about migrant stories; the project earned local press and a municipal grant.
Has a recurring tension with family over the riskiness of freelance life vs. the desire to pursue a creative career.
Keeps a small emergency fund in cash at home for unpredictable expenses; still feels financial vulnerability acutely.
Is registered to vote and typically supports Morena or progressive local candidates, but sometimes votes for smaller leftist parties depending on local stances.
Prefers to learn through doing rather than formal certification; values apprenticeships and practical workshops.
Participated in a student protest in university against budget cuts; learned strategic organizing and coalition-building there.
Has experienced minor thefts (bicycle and a stolen laptop once) which shaped his caution about leaving valuables unattended.
Enjoys teaching occasional free workshops for neighborhood youth about basic layout and poster-making to encourage creative expression.
Has a small side income from selling prints at monthly zine fairs and occasionally receives commissions from independent labels.
Maintains a catalog of favorite local printers and suppliers with notes on pricing and turnaround times — a key resource for his workflow.
Tries to keep a rotation of three personal projects at a time: a photo series, a zine, and a long-term mural proposal.
Often cycles to work and prefers active transportation when feasible to stay within a small budget and for environmental reasons.
Is cautious about taking on large loans; uses small-scale credit (store credit, micro-loans) in emergencies but prefers to avoid debt.
Has built a modest client referral system: satisfied clients recommend friends, which helps smooth income volatility.
Enjoys cooking family recipes, especially mole verde that his mother taught him; sees cooking as a creative practice.
Has a scar on his left knuckle from a carpentry accident while building a display for a market stall; wears it as a practical reminder about craft safety.
Keeps a list of 'organizations to support' including community health clinics, refugee assistance groups, and independent media outlets.
Was once shortlisted for a small national student design award which boosted confidence and early freelance opportunities.
Often feels torn between pursuing more stable formal employment (e.g., creative department at an NGO) and keeping freelance independence.
Has a dream project to create a bilingual (Spanish/English) magazine about urban mestizo culture and contemporary crafts.
Maintains a scrapbook of press clippings, posters, and ticket stubs from shows he organized — a physical archive of his creative life.
Feels pride in being part of a wave of young urban creatives who are trying to keep Mexican cultural forms alive while experimenting with new formats.
Is sensitive to housing precarity in CDMX and is involved in neighborhood efforts to pressure landlords and advocate for rent control policies.
